questions.question:
If AD = 34 cm, AB = 30 cm, the distance of AB from the centre of the circle is :
(A) 17 cm
(B) 15 cm
(C) 4 cm
(D) 8 cm
questions.solution:
Given: Diameter AD = 34 cm $\Rightarrow$ Radius $r = 17$ cm.
Chord AB = 30 cm.
Draw $OM \perp AB$. Then M bisects AB, so $AM = 15$ cm.
In right $\triangle OMA$:
$OM^2 = OA^2 - AM^2$
$OM^2 = 17^2 - 15^2$
$OM^2 = 289 - 225 = 64$
$OM = 8$ cm.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='20' y1='100' x2='180' y2='100' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='15' y='105' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='185' y='105' font-size='12'>D</text><line x1='60' y1='140' x2='140' y2='140' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='145' y='145' font-size='12'>B</text><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='2' fill='black'/><text x='100' y='90' font-size='12'>O</text><line x1='100' y1='100' x2='100' y2='140' stroke='#333' stroke-dasharray='4'/><text x='105' y='130' font-size='12'>M</text><line x1='100' y1='100' x2='140' y2='140' stroke='#333' stroke-dasharray='4'/></svg>

questions.question:
In Fig. 10.3, if OA = 5 cm, AB = 8 cm and OD is perpendicular to AB, then CD is equal to:
(A) 2 cm
(B) 3 cm
(C) 4 cm
(D) 5 cm
questions.solution:
Given OA = 5 cm (Radius).
Since $OD \perp AB$, it bisects AB. So $AC = CB = 4$ cm.
In right $\triangle OCA$:
$OC^2 = OA^2 - AC^2$
$OC^2 = 5^2 - 4^2 = 25 - 16 = 9$
$OC = 3$ cm.
Now, $CD = OD - OC = \text{Radius} - OC = 5 - 3 = 2$ cm.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='100' y1='100' x2='100' y2='180' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='105' y='195' font-size='12'>D</text><line x1='40' y1='150' x2='160' y2='150' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='30' y='155' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='165' y='155' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='105' y='145' font-size='12'>C</text><line x1='100' y1='100' x2='40' y2='150' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='100' y='90' font-size='12'>O</text></svg>

questions.question:
If AB = 12 cm, BC = 16 cm and AB is perpendicular to BC, then the radius of the circle passing through the points A, B and C is :
(A) 6 cm
(B) 8 cm
(C) 10 cm
(D) 12 cm
questions.solution:
Since $AB \perp BC$, $\angle B = 90^\circ$.
The angle in a semicircle is a right angle, so AC must be the diameter of the circle.
Using Pythagoras theorem in $\triangle ABC$:
$AC^2 = AB^2 + BC^2$
$AC^2 = 12^2 + 16^2 = 144 + 256 = 400$
$AC = 20$ cm.
Radius = $\frac{1}{2} \times AC = 10$ cm.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='40' y1='140' x2='160' y2='60' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='30' y='145' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='165' y='65' font-size='12'>C</text><line x1='40' y1='140' x2='120' y2='160' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='120' y='175' font-size='12'>B</text><line x1='120' y1='160' x2='160' y2='60' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/></svg>

questions.question:
In Fig.10.4, if $\angle ABC = 20^\circ$, then $\angle AOC$ is equal to:
(A) $20^\circ$
(B) $40^\circ$
(C) $60^\circ$
(D) $10^\circ$
questions.solution:
The angle subtended by an arc at the centre is double the angle subtended by it at any point on the remaining part of the circle.
$\angle AOC = 2 \times \angle ABC$
$\angle AOC = 2 \times 20^\circ = 40^\circ$.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='2' fill='black'/><text x='95' y='90' font-size='12'>O</text><path d='M 60 160 L 100 100 L 140 160' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><path d='M 60 160 L 100 30 L 140 160' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><text x='50' y='170' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='145' y='170' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='95' y='25' font-size='12'>B</text></svg>

questions.question:
In Fig.10.5, if AOB is a diameter of the circle and AC = BC, then $\angle CAB$ is equal to:
(A) $30^\circ$
(B) $60^\circ$
(C) $90^\circ$
(D) $45^\circ$
questions.solution:
Since AOB is a diameter, $\angle ACB = 90^\circ$ (Angle in a semicircle).
Given AC = BC, so $\triangle ABC$ is an isosceles right-angled triangle.
Therefore, $\angle CAB = \angle CBA$.
$\angle CAB + \angle CBA + 90^\circ = 180^\circ$
$2\angle CAB = 90^\circ$
$\angle CAB = 45^\circ$.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='20' y1='100' x2='180' y2='100' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='10' y='105' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='185' y='105' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='100' y='115' font-size='12'>O</text><path d='M 20 100 L 100 20 L 180 100' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><text x='95' y='15' font-size='12'>C</text></svg>

questions.question:
In Fig. 10.6, if $\angle OAB = 40^\circ$, then $\angle ACB$ is equal to :
(A) $50^\circ$
(B) $40^\circ$
(C) $60^\circ$
(D) $70^\circ$
questions.solution:
In $\triangle OAB$, $OA = OB$ (Radii).
So, $\angle OBA = \angle OAB = 40^\circ$.
$\angle AOB = 180^\circ - (40^\circ + 40^\circ) = 100^\circ$.
Angle at circumference $\angle ACB = \frac{1}{2} \angle AOB = \frac{1}{2} \times 100^\circ = 50^\circ$.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='2' fill='black'/><text x='100' y='115' font-size='12'>O</text><path d='M 60 150 L 100 100 L 140 150' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><path d='M 60 150 L 100 30 L 140 150' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><text x='50' y='160' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='145' y='160' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='95' y='25' font-size='12'>C</text></svg>

questions.question:
In Fig. 10.7, if $\angle DAB = 60^\circ$, $\angle ABD = 50^\circ$, then $\angle ACB$ is equal to:
(A) $60^\circ$
(B) $50^\circ$
(C) $70^\circ$
(D) $80^\circ$
questions.solution:
In $\triangle ABD$:
$\angle ADB = 180^\circ - (\angle DAB + \angle ABD)$
$\angle ADB = 180^\circ - (60^\circ + 50^\circ) = 70^\circ$.
Angles in the same segment are equal, so $\angle ACB = \angle ADB = 70^\circ$.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 60 160 L 140 160' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><text x='50' y='170' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='145' y='170' font-size='12'>B</text><path d='M 60 160 L 120 40 L 140 160' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><text x='115' y='35' font-size='12'>C</text><path d='M 60 160 L 80 40 L 140 160' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><text x='75' y='35' font-size='12'>D</text></svg>

questions.question:
ABCD is a cyclic quadrilateral such that AB is a diameter of the circle circumscribing it and $\angle ADC = 140^\circ$, then $\angle BAC$ is equal to:
(A) $80^\circ$
(B) $50^\circ$
(C) $40^\circ$
(D) $30^\circ$
questions.solution:
ABCD is a cyclic quadrilateral, so opposite angles sum to $180^\circ$.
$\angle ABC + \angle ADC = 180^\circ \Rightarrow \angle ABC = 180^\circ - 140^\circ = 40^\circ$.
Since AB is a diameter, $\angle ACB = 90^\circ$.
In $\triangle ABC$:
$\angle BAC = 180^\circ - (\angle ACB + \angle ABC)$
$\angle BAC = 180^\circ - (90^\circ + 40^\circ) = 50^\circ$.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='20' y1='100' x2='180' y2='100' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='10' y='105' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='185' y='105' font-size='12'>B</text><path d='M 20 100 L 80 170 L 140 170 L 180 100' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><text x='75' y='185' font-size='12'>D</text><text x='145' y='185' font-size='12'>C</text></svg>

questions.question:
In Fig. 10.8, BC is a diameter of the circle and $\angle BAO = 60^\circ$. Then $\angle ADC$ is equal to :
(A) $30^\circ$
(B) $45^\circ$
(C) $60^\circ$
(D) $120^\circ$
questions.solution:
In $\triangle AOB$, $OA = OB$ (Radii).
So, $\angle OBA = \angle BAO = 60^\circ$.
Angles in the same segment are equal, so $\angle ADC = \angle ABC$ (or $\angle OBA$).
Therefore, $\angle ADC = 60^\circ$.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='20' y1='100' x2='180' y2='100' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='10' y='105' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='185' y='105' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='100' y='115' font-size='12'>O</text><path d='M 20 100 L 80 40 L 180 100' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><text x='75' y='35' font-size='12'>A</text><path d='M 20 100 L 140 40 L 180 100' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><text x='135' y='35' font-size='12'>D</text></svg>

questions.question:
In Fig. 10.9, $\angle AOB = 90^\circ$ and $\angle ABC = 30^\circ$, then $\angle CAO$ is equal to:
(A) $30^\circ$
(B) $45^\circ$
(C) $90^\circ$
(D) $60^\circ$
questions.solution:
In $\triangle AOB$, $OA = OB$ and $\angle AOB = 90^\circ$.
So, $\angle OAB = \angle OBA = 45^\circ$.
Angle at circumference $\angle ACB = \frac{1}{2} \angle AOB = 45^\circ$.
In $\triangle ABC$:
$\angle BAC = 180^\circ - (\angle ABC + \angle ACB)$
$\angle BAC = 180^\circ - (30^\circ + 45^\circ) = 105^\circ$.
Now, $\angle CAO = \angle BAC - \angle OAB$
$\angle CAO = 105^\circ - 45^\circ = 60^\circ$.
